( 1 - italic_κ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + 4 italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + | 1 + italic_γ | ( italic_κ + 2 italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG ≥ 0 are some non-negative constants.

The proof of Theorem 2 is relegated to Appendix B. Notice that when κ=1𝜅1\kappa=1italic_κ = 1, we have β=0,C1=2⁢(1−η⁢L)formulae-sequence𝛽0subscript𝐶121𝜂𝐿\beta=0,C_{1}=2(1-\eta L)italic_β = 0 , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 ( 1 - italic_η italic_L ) and the convergence result recovers that of DPSGD (Ghadimi & Lan, 2013; Zhang et al., 2017). With this theorem, we can choose specific parameters and obtain the following corollary:

Corollary 1

Under the conditions of Theorem 2, choose γ=−1,𝛾1\gamma=-1,italic_γ = - 1 ,

η𝜂\displaystyle\etaitalic_η =min⁡{1L⁢(2+4/Cκ−Cκ),1Cκ⁢L⁢2⁢Cκ⁢L⁢(F⁢(𝐱0)−F⋆)+∥∇F⁢(𝐱0)∥2T⁢(2⁢σSGD2/B+d⁢σDP2)},absent1𝐿24subscript𝐶𝜅subscript𝐶𝜅1subscript𝐶𝜅𝐿2subscript𝐶𝜅𝐿𝐹subscript𝐱0superscript𝐹⋆superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐱02𝑇2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2SGD𝐵𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝜎2DP\displaystyle=\min\left\{\frac{1}{L(2+4/C_{\kappa}-C_{\kappa})},\frac{1}{C_{% \kappa}L}\sqrt{\frac{2C_{\kappa}L(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})-F^{\star})+\left\lVert% \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{0})\right\rVert^{2}}{T(2\sigma^{2}_{\mathrm{SGD}}/B+d% \sigma^{2}_{\mathrm{DP}})}}\right\},= roman_min { divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L ( 2 + 4 / italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ∥ ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_T ( 2 italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_B + italic_d italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG end_ARG } ,
β𝛽\displaystyle\betaitalic_β =η⁢(1−κ)/2+η2⁢L⁢(1−κ)2⁢(1+4⁢η2⁢L2)1−(1−κ)2⁢(1+4⁢η2⁢L2)≤12⁢Cκ⁢L,absent𝜂1𝜅2superscript𝜂2𝐿superscript1𝜅214superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿21superscript1𝜅214superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿212subscript𝐶𝜅𝐿\displaystyle=\frac{\eta(1-\kappa)/2+\eta^{2}L(1-\kappa)^{2}(1+4\eta^{2}L^{2})% }{1-(1-\kappa)^{2}(1+4\eta^{2}L^{2})}\leq\frac{1}{2C_{\kappa}L},= divide start_ARG italic_η ( 1 - italic_κ ) / 2 + italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L ( 1 - italic_κ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + 4 italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - italic_κ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + 4 italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_ARG ,
κ𝜅\displaystyle\kappaitalic_κ =Cκ⁢L⁢η≤1,and⁢Cκ=min⁡{∥∇F⁢(𝐱0)∥22⁢L⁢(F⁢(𝐱0)−F⋆),1},formulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝐶𝜅𝐿𝜂1andsubscript𝐶𝜅superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐱022𝐿𝐹subscript𝐱0superscript𝐹⋆1\displaystyle=C_{\kappa}L\eta\leq 1,\;\;\textrm{and}\;\;C_{\kappa}=\min\left\{% \frac{\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{0})\right\rVert^{2}}{2L(F(\mathbf{x}_{0}% )-F^{\star})},1\right\},= italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L italic_η ≤ 1 , and italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min { divide start_ARG ∥ ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG , 1 } ,

then Algorithm 3 satisfies:

1T⁢∑t=0T𝔼⁡[∥∇F⁢(𝐱t)∥2]≤4⁢CκL(F(𝐱0)−F⋆))(2σSGD2/B+dσDP2)T=𝒪⁢(dT).\frac{1}{T}\sum^{T}_{t=0}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf% {x}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}]\leq 4\sqrt{\frac{C_{\kappa}L(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})-F^{% \star}))(2\sigma^{2}_{\mathrm{SGD}}/B+d\sigma^{2}_{\mathrm{DP}})}{T}}=\mathcal% {O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{d}{T}}\right).divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ∥ ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 4 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ( 2 italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_B + italic_d italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_DP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG end_ARG = caligraphic_O ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG end_ARG ) . (9)

Convergence improvement: The above result implies that the order of the number of iterations T𝑇Titalic_T needed for convergence of Algorithm 3 is the same as of DPSGD (Ghadimi & Lan, 2013; Zhang et al., 2017). However, Algorithm 3 has a constant factor improvement in its convergence rate over DPSGD. This improvement is resulted from the presence of Cκ≤1subscript𝐶𝜅1C_{\kappa}\leq 1italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 1 in the numerator in the RHS of (9). More specifically, if Cκ<1,subscript𝐶𝜅1C_{\kappa}<1,italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 , i.e., ∥∇F⁢(𝐱0)∥2<2⁢L⁢(F⁢(𝐱0)−F⋆),superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐱022𝐿𝐹subscript𝐱0superscript𝐹⋆\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{0})\right\rVert^{2}<2L(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})-F^{% \star}),∥ ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 2 italic_L ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , then the convergence bound reduces by a factor of 1/Cκ,1subscript𝐶𝜅\sqrt{1/C_{\kappa}},square-root start_ARG 1 / italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , and DiSK  has clear theoretical improvement over vanilla DPSGD. Case I: For (μ𝜇\muitalic_μ-strongly) convex problems, it is guaranteed that 2⁢μ⁢(F⁢(𝐱0)−F⋆)≤∥∇F⁢(𝐱0)∥2≤2⁢L⁢(F⁢(𝐱0)−F⋆).2𝜇𝐹subscript𝐱0superscript𝐹⋆superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐱022𝐿𝐹subscript𝐱0superscript𝐹⋆2\mu(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})-F^{\star})\leq\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{0})\right% \rVert^{2}\leq 2L(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})-F^{\star}).2 italic_μ ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ ∥ ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ 2 italic_L ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . Therefore, the factor Cκ∈[μ/L,1].subscript𝐶𝜅𝜇𝐿1C_{\kappa}\in[\mu/L,1].italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_μ / italic_L , 1 ] . Case II: When training highly non-convex deep learning models, the Lipschitz constant L𝐿Litalic_L can be large (Herrera et al., 2020), and 2⁢L⁢(F⁢(𝐱0)−F⋆)2𝐿𝐹subscript𝐱0superscript𝐹⋆2L(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})-F^{\star})2 italic_L ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) can be much larger than ∥∇F⁢(𝐱0)∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝐱02\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{0})\right\rVert^{2}∥ ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which results in a considerable algorithm performance improvement compared to vanilla DPSGD.

While the above corollary is for the case of γ=−1𝛾1\gamma=-1italic_γ = - 1, we can obtain performance improvement for γ≠−1𝛾1\gamma\neq-1italic_γ ≠ - 1 as well. The choice γ=−1𝛾1\gamma=-1italic_γ = - 1 is optimized for the worst case (function satisfying our assumptions) based on our upper-bound in (2). However, it is possible that for functions satisfying additional assumptions, other choices of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ lead to better convergence result. This fact is further explained after presenting the proof of the theorem in Appendix B.2.

As a last remark in this subsecion, notice that our iteration complexity improvement does not require any additional assumption on the problem. In contrast, existing works with convergence improvement require additional assumptions, e.g., on the correlation between the gradients (Zhang et al., 2024a), or on the trace of Hessian (Choquette-Choo et al., 2024; Li et al., 2022).

4.2 Privacy-utility trade-off

To provide DP, the Subsampled Gaussian mechanism is used in Lines 4 and 5 of Algorithm 3. Instead of ∇f⁢(𝐱t;ξ)∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝜉\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t};\xi)∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ), we treat 1−κκ⁢γ⁢∇f⁢(𝐱t−γ⁢𝐝t−1;ξ)+(1−1−κκ⁢γ)⁢∇f⁢(𝐱t;ξ)1𝜅𝜅𝛾∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝛾subscript𝐝𝑡1𝜉11𝜅𝜅𝛾∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝜉\frac{1-\kappa}{\kappa\gamma}\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t}-\gamma\mathbf{d}_{t-1};% \xi)+(1-\frac{1-\kappa}{\kappa\gamma})\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t};\xi)divide start_ARG 1 - italic_κ end_ARG start_ARG italic_κ italic_γ end_ARG ∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_γ bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ) + ( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 - italic_κ end_ARG start_ARG italic_κ italic_γ end_ARG ) ∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ) as the per-sample gradient and apply the Subsampled Gaussian mechanism to privatize it. Therefore, Algorithm 3 and DPSGD share a similar privacy guarantee, as the privacy proof directly follows the Subsampled Gaussian mechanism and the composition of T𝑇Titalic_T iterations in Theorem 1. Specifically, by combining Theorem 1 and Theorem 2, we obtain the following privacy-utility trade-off:

Theorem 3

Assume A1-A3 holds. Run Algorithm 3 for T=2⁢N⁢ϵ⁢σSGDC⁢B⁢d⁢ln⁡(1/δ)𝑇2𝑁italic-ϵsubscript𝜎SGD𝐶𝐵𝑑1𝛿T=\frac{\sqrt{2}N\epsilon\sigma_{\mathrm{SGD}}}{C\sqrt{Bd\ln(1/\delta)}}italic_T = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_N italic_ϵ italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C square-root start_ARG italic_B italic_d roman_ln ( 1 / italic_δ ) end_ARG end_ARG iterations, and choose κ,β𝜅𝛽\kappa,\betaitalic_κ , italic_β according to the choices in Corollary 1, then

1T∑t=0T𝔼∥∇F(𝐱t)∥2≤8⁢C⁢σSGD⁢Cκ⁢L⁢(F⁢(𝐱0)−F⋆)⁢d⁢ln⁡(1/δ)B⁢N⁢ϵ=𝒪(d⁢ln⁡(1/δ)N⁢ϵ)\frac{1}{T}\sum^{T}_{t=0}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{% x}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{8C\sigma_{\mathrm{SGD}}\sqrt{C_{\kappa}L(F(% \mathbf{x}_{0})-F^{\star})d\ln(1/\delta)}}{\sqrt{B}N\epsilon}=\mathcal{O}\left% (\frac{\sqrt{d\ln(1/\delta)}}{N\epsilon}\right)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E ∥ ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 8 italic_C italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SGD end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L ( italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d roman_ln ( 1 / italic_δ ) end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_B end_ARG italic_N italic_ϵ end_ARG = caligraphic_O ( divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d roman_ln ( 1 / italic_δ ) end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_N italic_ϵ end_ARG ) (10)

Similar to our convergence result, compared to vanilla DPSGD, the privacy-utility trade-off of Algorithm 3 reduces by a constant factor of 1/Cκ1subscript𝐶𝜅\sqrt{1/C_{\kappa}}square-root start_ARG 1 / italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first theoretical result on the utility improvement of a DPSGD-type algorithm without any additional assumptions on the problem.

5 Numerical experiments

We perform extensive pre-training and fine-tuning experiments on various image classification (CV) and natural language processing (NLP) tasks using different base algorithms, privacy budgets, and models. The implementation details of the experiments are given in Appendix C.1. The link to the code is https://anonymous.4open.science/r/KalmanDP-BEDB.

5.1 Experiment settings

Dataset: We train the models on one synthetic dataset, four CV datasets, including MNIST (Deng, 2012), CIFAR-10/CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), and ImageNet-1k (Deng et al., 2009), and three NLP dataset, including GLUE (Wang et al., 2018), E2E (Novikova et al., 2017), and DART (Nan et al., 2021).

Model: For the CV tasks, we use three different models, including a 5-layer CNN, WideResNet (WRN) (De et al., 2022), and ViT (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020), representing three typical CV model structures. For the NLP task, we use the RoBERTa (Liu et al., 2019) and the GPT-2 (Radford et al., 2019) models. For pre-training, the models are initialized with random weights, and for fine-tuning with ViT, RoBERTa, and GPT-2, we directly use the checkpoints on HuggingFace (Wolf et al., 2020).

Algorithm: We use the DP version of SGD and Adam for CV tasks, and AdamW for NLP tasks as baselines. Then, we apply DiSK to compare their performance. Additional results on LoRA (Li et al., 2021) are given in Appendix C.4. In the results, we use KF- to denote the privatized version of the algorithms with the DiSK framework.

Hyper-parameter choices: We tune the hyper-parameters using a grid search. Specifically, we conduct a grid search on the batch size B𝐵Bitalic_B, total epochs E=N⁢T/B𝐸𝑁𝑇𝐵E=NT/Bitalic_E = italic_N italic_T / italic_B, and step size η𝜂\etaitalic_η for each given privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ. For all experiments, we fix the privacy parameter δ=1/N1.1𝛿1superscript𝑁1.1\delta=1/N^{1.1}italic_δ = 1 / italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1.1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain a reasonable privacy notion. Detailed hyper-parameter choices are discussed in Appendix C.2.

5.2 Numerical results

CV tasks: We first train the CV models with randomly initialized weights on different image datasets. The results for 5-layer CNN on the MNIST dataset, 5-layer CNN on the CIFAR-10 dataset, and WRN-16-4 on the CIFAR-100 datasets with different privacy budgets are given in Figure 1. DiSK  significantly outperforms the base algorithm across all used privacy budgets.

The test accuracy curves during the training for 5-layer CNN on the MNIST dataset, WRN-16-4 on the CIFAR-100 dataset, and ViT-small on the ImageNet-1k dataset are given in Figure 2. The optimizer with DiSK  convergence faster than the base algorithm on all tasks and reaches a higher final accuracy at a given privacy budget. The test accuracy of CIFAR-100 achieves 41.8%percent41.841.8\%41.8 %, and ImageNet-1k achieves 36.4%percent36.436.4\%36.4 %, which outperforms the SOTA results that apply data augmentation under the same privacy budget (40.6%percent40.640.6\%40.6 % for CIFAR-100 (Bao et al., 2024) and 32.4%percent32.432.4\%32.4 % for ImageNet-1k (De et al., 2022)). Additional comparisons on different models, algorithms, and fine-tuning CIFAR-100 are given in Appendix C.3.

NLP tasks: We fine-tune a pre-trained RoBERTa-base model111https://huggingface.co/FacebookAI/roberta-base on the GLUE datasets. The final test accuracy for is given in Table 1. We follow the same training script and hyper-parameter choices in the experiments as Bu et al. (2024). Compared with the base algorithm (DPAdamW), DiSK improves the final accuracy on all tasks by at least 3.8%percent3.83.8\%3.8 % when ϵ=1italic-ϵ1\epsilon=1italic_ϵ = 1 and 1.3%percent1.31.3\%1.3 % when ϵ=6.7italic-ϵ6.7\epsilon=6.7italic_ϵ = 6.7. Additional results for text generation tasks on the E2E ad DART datasets are given in Appendix C.4.

Ablation study: We conduct ablation studies on the choice of the hyper-parameters of DiSK, specifically, how κ,γ𝜅𝛾\kappa,\gammaitalic_κ , italic_γ impact the algorithm performance. The results are presented in Appendix C.3.

Improvements over the SOTA: Table LABEL:tab:app:sota in Appendix C.5 summarizes the improvements of DiSK over the SOTA on different tasks.

Reproducibility Statement

For the algorithm implementation, we provide a link to an anonymous downloadable source code in Section 5. We also discussed the data, model, and algorithms used in the experiment in Section 5 and in Appendix C. For our theoretical results provided in Section 4, we also include clear explanations of the assumptions in the section. The complete proof of the theorems can be found in Appendix B.

Broader Impact

This paper presents work that aims to advance the field of Machine Learning, combining optimization with signal processing and control societies. There are many potential societal consequences of our work, none of which we feel must be specifically highlighted here.

References

  • Abadi et al. (2016) Martin Abadi, Andy Chu, Ian Goodfellow, H Brendan McMahan, Ilya Mironov, Kunal Talwar, and Li Zhang. Deep learning with differential privacy. In Proceedings of the 2016 ACM SIGSAC conference on computer and communications security, pp.  308–318, 2016.
  • Allen-Zhu & Hazan (2016) Zeyuan Allen-Zhu and Elad Hazan. Variance reduction for faster non-convex optimization. In International conference on machine learning, pp.  699–707. PMLR, 2016.
  • Andrew et al. (2021) Galen Andrew, Om Thakkar, Brendan McMahan, and Swaroop Ramaswamy. Differentially private learning with adaptive clipping. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 34:17455–17466, 2021.
  • Badithela & Seiler (2019) Apurva Badithela and Peter Seiler. Analysis of the heavy-ball algorithm using integral quadratic constraints. In 2019 American control conference (ACC), pp.  4081–4085. IEEE, 2019.
  • Balle & Wang (2018) Borja Balle and Yu-Xiang Wang. Improving the gaussian mechanism for differential privacy: Analytical calibration and optimal denoising. In International Conference on Machine Learning, pp.  394–403. PMLR, 2018.
  • Bao et al. (2024) Wenxuan Bao, Francesco Pittaluga, Vijay Kumar BG, and Vincent Bindschaedler. Dp-mix: mixup-based data augmentation for differentially private learning. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 36, 2024.
  • Bittner & Pronzato (2004) Barbara Bittner and Luc Pronzato. Kalman filtering in stochastic gradient algorithms: construction of a stopping rule. In 2004 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing, volume 2, pp.  ii–709. IEEE, 2004.
  • Bu et al. (2023) Zhiqi Bu, Yu-Xiang Wang, Sheng Zha, and George Karypis. Differentially private optimization on large model at small cost. In International Conference on Machine Learning, pp.  3192–3218. PMLR, 2023.
  • Bu et al. (2024) Zhiqi Bu, Yu-Xiang Wang, Sheng Zha, and George Karypis. Automatic clipping: Differentially private deep learning made easier and stronger. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 36, 2024.
  • Chen et al. (2022) Xin Chen, Yujie Tang, and Na Li. Improve single-point zeroth-order optimization using high-pass and low-pass filters. In International Conference on Machine Learning, pp.  3603–3620. PMLR, 2022.
  • Choquette-Choo et al. (2024) Christopher A Choquette-Choo, Krishnamurthy Dj Dvijotham, Krishna Pillutla, Arun Ganesh, Thomas Steinke, and Abhradeep Guha Thakurta. Correlated noise provably beats independent noise for differentially private learning. In The Twelfth International Conference on Learning Representations, 2024.
  • Cutkosky & Orabona (2019) Ashok Cutkosky and Francesco Orabona. Momentum-based variance reduction in non-convex sgd. Advances in neural information processing systems, 32, 2019.
  • Cyrus et al. (2018) Saman Cyrus, Bin Hu, Bryan Van Scoy, and Laurent Lessard. A robust accelerated optimization algorithm for strongly convex functions. In 2018 Annual American Control Conference (ACC), pp.  1376–1381. IEEE, 2018.
  • De et al. (2022) Soham De, Leonard Berrada, Jamie Hayes, Samuel L Smith, and Borja Balle. Unlocking high-accuracy differentially private image classification through scale. arXiv preprint arXiv:2204.13650, 2022.
  • Deng et al. (2009) Jia Deng, Wei Dong, Richard Socher, Li-Jia Li, Kai Li, and Li Fei-Fei. Imagenet: A large-scale hierarchical image database. In 2009 IEEE conference on computer vision and pattern recognition, pp.  248–255. Ieee, 2009.
  • Deng (2012) Li Deng. The mnist database of handwritten digit images for machine learning research [best of the web]. IEEE signal processing magazine, 29(6):141–142, 2012.
  • Dosovitskiy et al. (2020) Alexey Dosovitskiy, Lucas Beyer, Alexander Kolesnikov, Dirk Weissenborn, Xiaohua Zhai, Thomas Unterthiner, Mostafa Dehghani, Matthias Minderer, Georg Heigold, Sylvain Gelly, et al. An image is worth 16x16 words: Transformers for image recognition at scale. In International Conference on Learning Representations, 2020.
  • Dwork & Roth (2014) Cynthia Dwork and Aaron Roth. The algorithmic foundations of differential privacy. Theoretical Computer Science, 9(3-4):211–407, 2014.
  • Ghadimi & Lan (2013) Saeed Ghadimi and Guanghui Lan. Stochastic first-and zeroth-order methods for nonconvex stochastic programming. SIAM journal on optimization, 23(4):2341–2368, 2013.
  • Herrera et al. (2020) Calypso Herrera, Florian Krach, and Josef Teichmann. Estimating full lipschitz constants of deep neural networks. arXiv preprint arXiv:2004.13135, 2020.
  • Hu & Lessard (2017) Bin Hu and Laurent Lessard. Dissipativity theory for nesterov’s accelerated method. In International Conference on Machine Learning, pp.  1549–1557. PMLR, 2017.
  • Hu et al. (2021) Yuhang Hu, Zhou Tan, Xianxian Li, Jinyan Wang, et al. Adaptive clipping bound of deep learning with differential privacy. In 2021 IEEE 20th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom), pp.  428–435. IEEE, 2021.
  • Jayaraman & Evans (2019) Bargav Jayaraman and David Evans. Evaluating differentially private machine learning in practice. In 28th USENIX Security Symposium (USENIX Security 19), pp.  1895–1912, 2019.

Appendix A Additional discussion

A.1 Background on Kalman Filter

In this section, we provide an introduction and derivation of the Kalman filter. Kalman filter is introduced in (Kalman, 1960) and wildly used for control systems in accurately estimating system states with noisy observation and known system dynamics. Kalman filter assumes the system is a linear (time-invariant) system:

𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐀⁢𝜽t−1+𝐮t+𝐯t,absent𝐀subscript𝜽𝑡1subscript𝐮𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t-1}+\mathbf{u}_{t}+\mathbf{v}_{t},= bold_A bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (System update)
𝝍tsubscript𝝍𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐂⁢𝜽t+𝐰t,absent𝐂subscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbf{C}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}+\mathbf{w}_{t},= bold_C bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (Observation)

where 𝐀,𝐂𝐀𝐂\mathbf{A},\mathbf{C}bold_A , bold_C are known matrix, and 𝐯t∼𝒩(0,Σ𝐯),𝐰t∼𝒩(,Σ𝐰)\mathbf{v}_{t}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}),\mathbf{w}_{t}\sim% \mathcal{N}(,\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) follows Gaussian distributions with known covariance matrices Σ𝐯,Σ𝐰subscriptΣ𝐯subscriptΣ𝐰\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}},\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and 𝐮tsubscript𝐮𝑡\mathbf{u}_{t}bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is known input signal. The goal of the Kalman filter is to estimate 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the observation of 𝝍tsubscript𝝍𝑡\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the least mean-square error.

Derivation: First, we denote the estimation of 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as 𝜽~tsubscript~𝜽𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the covariance of 𝜽t−𝜽~tsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as

𝐏t=𝔼⁡[(𝜽t−𝜽~t)⁢(𝜽t−𝜽~t)⊤],subscript𝐏𝑡𝔼subscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽𝑡top\mathbf{P}_{t}=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{% \boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t})(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_% {t})^{\top}],bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E [ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ,

Then, the system dynamics give an unbiased prediction:

𝜽~t|t−1=𝐀⁢𝜽~t−1+𝐮t,subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1𝐀subscript~𝜽𝑡1subscript𝐮𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}=\mathbf{A}\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t-1% }+\mathbf{u}_{t},over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_A over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (11)

and its covariance is

𝐏t|t−1=𝔼⁡[(𝜽t−𝜽~t|t−1)⁢(𝜽t−𝜽~t|t−1)⊤]=𝐀𝐏t−1⁢𝐀⊤+Σ𝐯.subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1𝔼subscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1topsubscript𝐀𝐏𝑡1superscript𝐀topsubscriptΣ𝐯\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{% \boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1})(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{% \theta}}_{t|t-1})^{\top}]=\mathbf{A}\mathbf{P}_{t-1}\mathbf{A}^{\top}+\Sigma_{% \mathbf{v}}.bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E [ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = bold_AP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (12)

With 𝜽~t|t−1subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have the prediction error Δ⁢𝝍t=𝝍t−𝐂⁢𝝍~t|t−1.Δsubscript𝝍𝑡subscript𝝍𝑡𝐂subscript~𝝍conditional𝑡𝑡1\Delta\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}=\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}-\mathbf{C}\tilde{\boldsymbol% {\psi}}_{t|t-1}.roman_Δ bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_C over~ start_ARG bold_italic_ψ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Since the system is linear, we would like to use the prediction error to correct the prediction:

𝜽~t=𝜽~t|t−1+𝐊t⁢Δ⁢𝝍t=𝐊t⁢𝝍t+(𝐈−𝐊t⁢𝐂)⁢𝜽~t|t−1.subscript~𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡Δsubscript𝝍𝑡subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝝍𝑡𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}+\mathbf{K}% _{t}\Delta\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}=\mathbf{K}_{t}\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}+(\mathbf{I% }-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}.over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (13)

The goal of the Kalman filter is to minimize the mean-square error: min𝐊⁡𝔼⁡[∥𝜽t−𝜽~t∥2],subscript𝐊𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽𝑡2\min_{\mathbf{K}}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\left\lVert\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-% \tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}\right\rVert^{2}],roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ∥ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , which is equivalent to minimizing tr⁢(𝐏t).trsubscript𝐏𝑡\mathrm{tr}(\mathbf{P}_{t}).roman_tr ( bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . From the definition of 𝜽~t,subscript~𝜽𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t},over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , we have:

𝐏tsubscript𝐏𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝔼⁡[(𝜽t−𝜽~t)⁢(𝜽t−𝜽~t)⊤]absent𝔼subscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽𝑡top\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{% \boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t})(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_% {t})^{\top}]= blackboard_E [ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]
=𝔼⁡[(𝜽t−𝐊t⁢𝝍t+(𝐈−𝐊t⁢𝐂)⁢𝜽~t|t−1)⁢(𝜽t−𝐊t⁢𝝍t+(𝐈−𝐊t⁢𝐂)⁢𝜽~t|t−1)⊤]absent𝔼subscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝝍𝑡𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝝍𝑡𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1top\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\mathbf{K}_{t% }\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}+(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\tilde{\boldsymbol% {\theta}}_{t|t-1})(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}% +(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1})^{% \top}]= blackboard_E [ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]
=𝔼⁡[(𝜽t−𝜽~t|t−1−𝐊t⁢𝐂⁢(𝜽t−𝜽~t|t−1)−𝐊t⁢𝐰t)⁢(𝜽t−𝜽~t|t−1−𝐊t⁢𝐂⁢(𝜽t−𝜽~t|t−1)−𝐊t⁢𝐰t)⊤]absent𝔼subscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript𝜽𝑡subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡top\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{% \boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-% \tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1})-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{w}_{t})(\boldsymbol% {\theta}_{t}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C}(% \boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1})-\mathbf{K}_{t}% \mathbf{w}_{t})^{\top}]= blackboard_E [ ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]
=𝐏t|t−1−𝐊t⁢𝐂𝐏t|t−1−(𝐊t⁢𝐂𝐏t|t−1)⊤+𝐊t⁢(𝐂𝐏t|t−1⁢𝐂⊤+Σ𝐰)⁢𝐊t⊤.absentsubscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1topsubscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscript𝐂topsubscriptΣ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐊𝑡top\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}-(% \mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1})^{\top}+\mathbf{K}_{t}(\mathbf{C}% \mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\mathbf{C}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})\mathbf{K}_{t}^{\top}.= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Taking partial derivative to the trace of 𝐏tsubscript𝐏𝑡\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to 𝐊tsubscript𝐊𝑡\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and set it to zero, we have:

∂tr⁢(𝐏t)∂𝐊t=−2⁢(𝐂𝐏t|t−1)⊤+2⁢(𝐂𝐏t|t−1⁢𝐂⊤+Σ𝐰)⁢𝐊t⊤=0,trsubscript𝐏𝑡subscript𝐊𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1top2subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscript𝐂topsubscriptΣ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐊𝑡top0\frac{\partial\mathrm{tr}(\mathbf{P}_{t})}{\partial\mathbf{K}_{t}}=-2(\mathbf{% C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1})^{\top}+2(\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\mathbf{C}^{\top}+% \Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})\mathbf{K}_{t}^{\top}=0,divide start_ARG ∂ roman_tr ( bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = - 2 ( bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 ( bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 ,

which gives

𝐊t=𝐏t|t−1⁢𝐂⊤⁢(𝐂𝐏t|t−1⁢𝐂⊤+Σ𝐰)−1.subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscript𝐂topsuperscriptsubscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscript𝐂topsubscriptΣ𝐰1\mathbf{K}_{t}=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\mathbf{C}^{\top}(\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1% }\mathbf{C}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})^{-1}.bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (14)

Substitute 𝐊tsubscript𝐊𝑡\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT back to 𝐏t,subscript𝐏𝑡\mathbf{P}_{t},bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , we can simplify

𝐏tsubscript𝐏𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐏t|t−1−𝐊t⁢𝐂𝐏t|t−1−(𝐊t⁢𝐂𝐏t|t−1)⊤+𝐊t⁢(𝐂𝐏t|t−1⁢𝐂⊤+Σ𝐰)⁢𝐊t⊤absentsubscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1topsubscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscript𝐂topsubscriptΣ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐊𝑡top\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}-(% \mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1})^{\top}+\mathbf{K}_{t}(\mathbf{C}% \mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\mathbf{C}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})\mathbf{K}_{t}^{\top}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (15)
=𝐏t|t−1−𝐊t⁢𝐂𝐏t|t−1=(𝐈−𝐊t⁢𝐂)⁢𝐏t|t−1.absentsubscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}=(% \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}.= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Combining (11)-(15) together, we have the update of the Kalman filter:

𝜽~t|t−1subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐀⁢𝜽~t−1+𝐮tabsent𝐀subscript~𝜽𝑡1subscript𝐮𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbf{A}\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t-1}+\mathbf{u}_{t}= bold_A over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
𝐏t|t−1subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐀𝐏t−1⁢𝐀⊤+Σ𝐯absentsubscript𝐀𝐏𝑡1superscript𝐀topsubscriptΣ𝐯\displaystyle=\mathbf{A}\mathbf{P}_{t-1}\mathbf{A}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}= bold_AP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
𝐊tsubscript𝐊𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐏t|t−1⁢𝐂⊤⁢(𝐂𝐏t|t−1⁢𝐂⊤+Σ𝐰)−1absentsubscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscript𝐂topsuperscriptsubscript𝐂𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscript𝐂topsubscriptΣ𝐰1\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\mathbf{C}^{\top}(\mathbf{C}\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}% \mathbf{C}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}})^{-1}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_CP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
𝜽~tsubscript~𝜽𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(𝐈−𝐊t⁢𝐂)⁢𝜽~t|t−1+𝐊t⁢𝝍tabsent𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript~𝜽conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝝍𝑡\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}% _{t|t-1}+\mathbf{K}_{t}\boldsymbol{\psi}_{t}= ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) over~ start_ARG bold_italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
𝐏tsubscript𝐏𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(𝐈−𝐊t⁢𝐂)⁢𝐏t|t−1.absent𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡𝐂subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\mathbf{C})\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}.= ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C ) bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Variants of Kalman filter: Kalman filter is designed for estimating the states following linear dynamics and achieves optimal performance, i.e., gives the smallest mean square error of the estimation when the system is linear (Welch et al., 1995). Extended Kalman filter (EKF) and unscented Kalman filter (UKF) are developed to deal with non-linear systems. EKF linearizes the non-linear system at each step and performs the Kalman filter on the linearized system (Ribeiro, 2004), while UKF takes the effect of the system non-linearity to the noise distribution into consideration and applies the unscented transform on the noise distribution and applies the Kalman filter on the system and the noise distribution (Wan & Van Der Merwe, 2001). Other extensions of the Kalman filter have been developed for special cases, including multiplicative noise and noisy input 𝐮tsubscript𝐮𝑡\mathbf{u}_{t}bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Wu et al., 2016).

A.2 Other system dynamics for DPSGD

In this section, we want to discuss other possible formulations of the system dynamics for DPSGD to apply the Kalman filter.

Optimization variable and gradient version 1: Other than only using the gradients’ dynamics in the main paper, we can construct the system taking the dynamics of the optimization variable 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x into the system (Vuckovic, 2018):

[𝐱t+1∇F⁢(𝐱t+1)]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑡1∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡1\displaystyle\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbf{x}_{t+1}\\ \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t+1})\end{array}\right][ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] =[𝐈−η⁢𝐈0𝐈]⁢[𝐱t∇F⁢(𝐱t)]+[η⁢𝐰t0],absentdelimited-[]𝐈𝜂𝐈0𝐈delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡delimited-[]𝜂subscript𝐰𝑡0\displaystyle=\left[\begin{array}[]{cc}\mathbf{I}&-\eta\mathbf{I}\\ 0&\mathbf{I}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbf{x}_{t}\\ \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\eta\mathbf% {w}_{t}\\ 0\end{array}\right],= [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_I end_CELL start_CELL - italic_η bold_I end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL bold_I end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] + [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_η bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] ,
𝐲tsubscript𝐲𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{y}_{t}bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐱t.absentsubscript𝐱𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{t}.= bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

However, this dynamic is inaccurate as the dynamics of the gradient are simplified to ∇F⁢(𝐱t+1)=∇F⁢(𝐱t)∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡1∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t+1})=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Although the update can further incorporate with the momentum methods, i.e., by adding a momentum 𝐦tsubscript𝐦𝑡\mathbf{m}_{t}bold_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into the system, it fails to reveal the actual dynamic of the system.

Optimization variable and gradient version 2: Instead of treating the gradient as a constant, we can further utilize the Hessian to reveal the gradient dynamics:

[𝐱t+1𝐱t∇F⁢(𝐱t)]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑡1subscript𝐱𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡\displaystyle\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbf{x}_{t+1}\\ \mathbf{x}_{t}\\ \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})\end{array}\right][ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] =[𝐈−η⁢𝐇η⁢𝐇−η⁢𝐈𝐈00𝐇−𝐇𝐈]⁢[𝐱t𝐱t−1∇F⁢(𝐱t−1)]+[η⁢𝐰t00],absentdelimited-[]𝐈𝜂𝐇𝜂𝐇𝜂𝐈𝐈00𝐇𝐇𝐈delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡1∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡1delimited-[]𝜂subscript𝐰𝑡00\displaystyle=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccc}\mathbf{I}-\eta\mathbf{H}&\eta\mathbf{% H}&-\eta\mathbf{I}\\ \mathbf{I}&0&0\\ \mathbf{H}&-\mathbf{H}&\mathbf{I}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}[]{c}% \mathbf{x}_{t}\\ \mathbf{x}_{t-1}\\ \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t-1})\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\eta% \mathbf{w}_{t}\\ 0\\ 0\end{array}\right],= [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_I - italic_η bold_H end_CELL start_CELL italic_η bold_H end_CELL start_CELL - italic_η bold_I end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_I end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_H end_CELL start_CELL - bold_H end_CELL start_CELL bold_I end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] + [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_η bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] ,
𝐲tsubscript𝐲𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{y}_{t}bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐱t.absentsubscript𝐱𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{t}.= bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

This system is more accurate in evaluating the gradient at the cost of using an extra 𝐱t−1subscript𝐱𝑡1\mathbf{x}_{t-1}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT state and a larger transition matrix. For non-linear problems F⁢(𝐱)𝐹𝐱F(\mathbf{x})italic_F ( bold_x ), where 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H is not a constant, we can apply the extended Kalman filter and replace 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H with 𝐇tsubscript𝐇𝑡\mathbf{H}_{t}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that linearizes the problem at each time step.

Gradient and Hessian: In work (Bittner & Pronzato, 2004), the dynamics of the gradient and Hessian have been used to construct the system:

[∇F⁢(𝐱t+1)𝐡t+1]delimited-[]∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡1subscript𝐡𝑡1\displaystyle\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t+1})\\ \mathbf{h}_{t+1}\end{array}\right][ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] =[𝐈Δ⁢𝐗t0𝐈]⁢[∇F⁢(𝐱t)𝐡t],absentdelimited-[]𝐈Δsubscript𝐗𝑡0𝐈delimited-[]∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐡𝑡\displaystyle=\left[\begin{array}[]{cc}\mathbf{I}&\Delta\mathbf{X}_{t}\\ 0&\mathbf{I}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})% \\ \mathbf{h}_{t}\end{array}\right],= [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_I end_CELL start_CELL roman_Δ bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL bold_I end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] ,
𝐠tsubscript𝐠𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{g}_{t}bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =∇F⁢(𝐱t)+𝐰t,absent∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{t})+\mathbf{w}_{t},= ∇ italic_F ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where 𝐡t=[𝐇1,1,…,𝐇i,i+j,…,𝐇d,d]⊤,subscript𝐡𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐇11…subscript𝐇𝑖𝑖𝑗…subscript𝐇𝑑𝑑top\mathbf{h}_{t}=[\mathbf{H}_{1,1},\dots,\mathbf{H}_{i,i+j},\dots,\mathbf{H}_{d,% d}]^{\top},bold_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_i + italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , with j∈[0,…,d−i]𝑗0…𝑑𝑖j\in[0,\dots,d-i]italic_j ∈ [ 0 , … , italic_d - italic_i ] represents the entries in the upper triangular part of the Hessian matrix. Δ⁢𝐗tΔsubscript𝐗𝑡\Delta\mathbf{X}_{t}roman_Δ bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is constructed such that Δ⁢𝐗t⁢𝐡t=𝐇t⁢(𝐱t+1−𝐱t).Δsubscript𝐗𝑡subscript𝐡𝑡subscript𝐇𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡1subscript𝐱𝑡\Delta\mathbf{X}_{t}\mathbf{h}_{t}=\mathbf{H}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t+1}-\mathbf{x}_% {t}).roman_Δ bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . The system treats the Hessian matrix as a constant matrix, and the transition matrix is of size (d+d⁢(d−1)/2)×d+d⁢(d−1)/2.𝑑𝑑𝑑12𝑑𝑑𝑑12(d+d(d-1)/2)\times d+d(d-1)/2.( italic_d + italic_d ( italic_d - 1 ) / 2 ) × italic_d + italic_d ( italic_d - 1 ) / 2 .

Although there are different ways to construct the Kamlan filter for gradient noise reduction, the above systems are not implementable in practical deep-learning applications. Because the transition matrices of these systems are non-diagonal, the Kalman filters have non-diagonal gain 𝐊tsubscript𝐊𝑡\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐏tsubscript𝐏𝑡\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, the matrix inversion operation is unavoidable when Kalman filters are implemented based on these systems. The computation complexity for the matrix inversion can be 𝒪⁢(d3)𝒪superscript𝑑3\mathcal{O}(d^{3})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) to 𝒪⁢(d6),𝒪superscript𝑑6\mathcal{O}(d^{6}),caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , and the memory consumption is 𝒪⁢(d2)𝒪superscript𝑑2\mathcal{O}(d^{2})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) to 𝒪⁢(d4)𝒪superscript𝑑4\mathcal{O}(d^{4})caligraphic_O ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for storing the matrices of the Kalman filter.

A.3 Algorithm Simplification

In this section, we explain how the simplification proceeds from Algorithm 2 to Algorithm 3. Recall that updates of Algorithm 2 is

𝐠~t|t−1subscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐠~t−1+𝐇~t⁢(𝐱t−𝐱t−1)absentsubscript~𝐠𝑡1subscript~𝐇𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t-1}+\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-% \mathbf{x}_{t-1})= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_H end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Prediction)
𝐏t|t−1subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐏t−1+Σ𝐇+Σ𝐯absentsubscript𝐏𝑡1subscriptΣ𝐇subscriptΣ𝐯\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t-1}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
𝐊tsubscript𝐊𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐏t|t−1𝔼[𝐂t]⊤(Σ𝐰+𝔼[𝐂t](Σ𝐂𝐒t+𝐏t|t−1)𝔼[𝐂t]⊤−Σ𝐇)−1\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]^{% \top}\left(\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}}+\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]\left(% \Sigma_{\mathbf{C}}\mathbf{S}_{t}+\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\right)\operatorname{% \mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]^{\top}-\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}\right)^{-1}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
𝐠~tsubscript~𝐠𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐠~t|t−1+𝐊t⁢(𝐠t−𝔼⁡[𝐂t]⁢𝐠~t|t−1)absentsubscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐠𝑡𝔼subscript𝐂𝑡subscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}+\mathbf{K}_{t}(\mathbf{g}_{t}-% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{t}]\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1})= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Correction)
𝐏tsubscript𝐏𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(𝐈−𝐊t⁢𝔼⁡[𝐂t])⁢𝐏t|t−1absent𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡𝔼subscript𝐂𝑡subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\mathbf{C}_{% t}])\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}= ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
𝐒tsubscript𝐒𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{S}_{t}bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝔼⁡[𝐠~t⁢𝐠~t⊤],absent𝔼subscript~𝐠𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑡top\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}\tilde{\mathbf{g% }}_{t}^{\top}],= blackboard_E [ over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ,

where 𝐠t=1B⁢∑ξ∈ℬtclip⁢(∇f⁢(𝐱t;ξ),C)+𝐰t.subscript𝐠𝑡1𝐵subscript𝜉subscriptℬ𝑡clip∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝜉𝐶subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{g}_{t}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{B}_{t}}\mathrm{clip}\left(% \nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t};\xi),C\right)+\mathbf{w}_{t}.bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ ∈ caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clip ( ∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ) , italic_C ) + bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . We apply four steps of simplification, including

  1. 1.

    Replacing random 𝐂tsubscript𝐂𝑡\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with constant 𝐈dsubscript𝐈𝑑\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Use finite difference to estimate 𝐇t⁢𝐝t−1subscript𝐇𝑡subscript𝐝𝑡1\mathbf{H}_{t}\mathbf{d}_{t-1}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  3. 3.

    Replace Σ𝐇subscriptΣ𝐇\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with diagonal matrix σH2⁢𝐈dsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐻subscript𝐈𝑑\sigma^{2}_{H}\mathbf{I}_{d}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Σ𝐯subscriptΣ𝐯\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with σ𝐯2⁢𝐈dsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐯subscript𝐈𝑑\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}\mathbf{I}_{d}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Σ𝐰subscriptΣ𝐰\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with σ𝐰2⁢𝐈dsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐰subscript𝐈𝑑\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}\mathbf{I}_{d}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  4. 4.

    Use fixed filter gain κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ.

Step 1. By replacing 𝐂tsubscript𝐂𝑡\mathbf{C}_{t}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with 𝐈dsubscript𝐈𝑑\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Σ𝐂=0subscriptΣ𝐂0\Sigma_{\mathbf{C}}=0roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the update becomes

𝐠~t|t−1subscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐠~t−1+𝐇~t⁢(𝐱t−𝐱t−1)absentsubscript~𝐠𝑡1subscript~𝐇𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t-1}+\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{t}-% \mathbf{x}_{t-1})= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_H end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Prediction)
𝐏t|t−1subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐏t−1+Σ𝐇+Σ𝐯absentsubscript𝐏𝑡1subscriptΣ𝐇subscriptΣ𝐯\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t-1}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}+\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
𝐊tsubscript𝐊𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{K}_{t}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐏t|t−1⁢(Σ𝐰+𝐏t|t−1−Σ𝐇)−1absentsubscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1superscriptsubscriptΣ𝐰subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1subscriptΣ𝐇1\displaystyle=\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}\left(\Sigma_{\mathbf{w}}+\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}-% \Sigma_{\mathbf{H}}\right)^{-1}= bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
𝐠~tsubscript~𝐠𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐠~t|t−1+𝐊t⁢(𝐠t−𝐠~t|t−1)absentsubscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐠𝑡subscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}+\mathbf{K}_{t}(\mathbf{g}_{t}-\tilde{% \mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1})= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Correction)
𝐏tsubscript𝐏𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{P}_{t}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(𝐈−𝐊t)⁢𝐏t|t−1.absent𝐈subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t})\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1}.= ( bold_I - bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Step 2. By using the finite difference to estimate 𝐇t⁢𝐝t−1subscript𝐇𝑡subscript𝐝𝑡1\mathbf{H}_{t}\mathbf{d}_{t-1}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the prediction step becomes:

𝐠~t|t−1=𝐠~t−1+1B⁢∑ξ∈ℬt∇f⁢(𝐱t+γ⁢𝐝t−1;ξ)−∇f⁢(𝐱t;ξ)γ(Prediction).subscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript~𝐠𝑡11𝐵subscript𝜉subscriptℬ𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝛾subscript𝐝𝑡1𝜉∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝜉𝛾(Prediction)\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t-1}+\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\xi\in% \mathcal{B}_{t}}\frac{\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t}+\gamma\mathbf{d}_{t-1};\xi)-% \nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t};\xi)}{\gamma}\qquad\textit{(Prediction)}.over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ ∈ caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ) - ∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG (Prediction) .

Step 3. By replacing ΣΣ\Sigmaroman_Σ’s with diagonal matrix σ2⁢𝐈dsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑑\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{d}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s, the update becomes:

𝐠~t|t−1subscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐠~t−1+1B⁢∑ξ∈ℬt∇f⁢(𝐱t+γ⁢𝐝t−1;ξ)−∇f⁢(𝐱t;ξ)γabsentsubscript~𝐠𝑡11𝐵subscript𝜉subscriptℬ𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝛾subscript𝐝𝑡1𝜉∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡𝜉𝛾\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t-1}+\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{B}_{t}}% \frac{\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t}+\gamma\mathbf{d}_{t-1};\xi)-\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_% {t};\xi)}{\gamma}= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ ∈ caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_γ bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ) - ∇ italic_f ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ξ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG (Prediction)
pt|t−1subscript𝑝conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle p_{t|t-1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =pt−1+σH2+σ𝐯2,𝐏t|t−1=pt|t−1⁢𝐈dformulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝑝𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐯subscript𝐏conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝑝conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝐈𝑑\displaystyle=p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{H}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}},\mathbf{P}_{t|t-1% }=p_{t|t-1}\mathbf{I}_{d}= italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
ktsubscript𝑘𝑡\displaystyle k_{t}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =pt|t−1pt|t−1+σ𝐰2−σH2=pt−1+σH2+σ𝐯2pt−1+σ𝐰2+σ𝐯2,𝐊t=kt⁢𝐈dformulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝑝conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝑝conditional𝑡𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐻subscript𝑝𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐯subscript𝑝𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐯subscript𝐊𝑡subscript𝑘𝑡subscript𝐈𝑑\displaystyle=\frac{p_{t|t-1}}{p_{t|t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}-\sigma^{2}_{H% }}=\frac{p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{H}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}}{p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{% \mathbf{w}}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}},\mathbf{K}_{t}=k_{t}\mathbf{I}_{d}= divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
𝐠~tsubscript~𝐠𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝐠~t|t−1+kt⁢(𝐠t−𝐠~t|t−1)absentsubscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1subscript𝑘𝑡subscript𝐠𝑡subscript~𝐠conditional𝑡𝑡1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t|t-1}+k_{t}(\mathbf{g}_{t}-\tilde{\mathbf{g% }}_{t|t-1})= over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Correction)
ptsubscript𝑝𝑡\displaystyle p_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(1−kt)⁢pt|t−1=(σ𝐰2−σH2)⁢(pt−1+σH2+σ𝐯2)pt−1+σ𝐰2+σ𝐯2.absent1subscript𝑘𝑡subscript𝑝conditional𝑡𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐻subscript𝑝𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐯subscript𝑝𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝐯\displaystyle=(1-k_{t})p_{t|t-1}=\frac{(\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{w}}-\sigma^{2}_{H}% )(p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{H}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}})}{p_{t-1}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf% {w}}+\sigma^{2}_{\mathbf{v}}}.= ( 1 - italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ( italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG .

Step 4. As discussed in the main paper, the update of kt,ptsubscript𝑘𝑡subscript𝑝𝑡k_{t},p_{t}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes:
